A retinol cream can be applied during the day... your skin is going to be sensitive to the cream regardless of time of day. Be sure to wear hats and sunscreen. Applying it at time time is not going to make your skin less sensitive just because you applied it 12 hours later.

Retinol/Retinal/Etc is definitely the only scientifically proven ingredient that works in preventing wrinkles/treating them, yes. Also, you can get it in serum form as well as in oil form, not just creams (my own skin prefers the feeling of creams, personally). However, there is also data on Vitamin C, Niacinamide (the super star ingredient in skincare because it helps with a lot of things), and various acids (aha, bha, and the gentler pha) all also have scientific backing, just not as much as Retinol. More so than things that have “antioxidants”. Also, yes, light is a no-no for retinol. Yes, it thins your skin and makes it more susceptible to sun damage. But the sun basically kills retinol. It deactivates it/makes it essentially worthless on your skin. So definitely don’t use it during the day. Also, micro encapsulation helps retinol become gentler on your skin because it’s released more slowly throughout the night. Also, after a while, low percentages of retinol will feel useless because your skin has adapted to it. So when this happens, it’s totally okay to go higher, like a 1.5, or 2.0, etc.

In terms of ingredients and packaging, basically:

AVOID
× Collagen (it's too large to get into skin it's bullshit)
× vitamin C on skin products
× "Active ingredient"
× "Clinically proven" (no real regulation),
× "Dermatologically tested"/"Demonologist tested for safety" (redundant; it's safe for use the FDA wouldn't allow it out otherwise)
× Dimethicone (it's a silicone based cream).

THE FOLLOWING A GOOD INGREDIENTS
✓ High glycerine
✓ Vitamin E based anti oxidant (eg. Bran oil)
✓ Aloe vera or honey,
✓ Retinol/rerinyl palmitate for anti aging only (it's a vitamin A strand; night only)
✓ Palmitoyl polypeptides (for night creams only due to thinning but helps skin).
DON'T FORGET SUN SCREEN!!

Actually retinoic acid is the active that does all the good things not retinol. Retinol needs to be converted by your skin into retinoic acid, which makes it VERY weak. Also retinoic acid thickens the dermis and thins the epidermis, specifically the dead cell layer because it causes faster cell turnover, it is also anti inflammatory which is why it is perscribed by doctors for acne. Fortunatelly, in greece you don't need a perscription for this and a 0.5 cream costs 3 euros. As for vitamins some claim that although they do not penetrate the skin they may help with free radicals. Collagen also does not penetrate the skin, but it is a humectant, meaning that it absorbs moisture from the environment, thus helping with mousturization. Dimethicone is kind of the opposite of a humectant, instead of absorbing moisture it blocks it, thus maintaining the skins own moisture from transepidermal water loss. Interesting video and I love how much information you got after seriously delving into skincare for only a short amount of time. Really cool. Buuut as someome who has been hardcore into skincare science for over a year I noticed some things that weren't true or misleading.

Topical collagen for example won't magically give your skin more collagen, that's true, but it's a great moisturizing ingredient actually. Not for anti-aging, but I guess it does "help reduce fine lines" and all that as moisturized skin is more plump. The claims at times are definitely ridiculous, but it's not useless if your goal is to moisturize your face.

Also, vitamin E and vitamin C are not the same thing, just because they're both antioxidants. 10% pure Ascorbic acid is a lot stronger and more effective (for various things, eg helping with hyperpigmentation) than Vitamin E. Equating them is misleading, and looking at where they are in the ingredients list is as well.

Which, btw, formulations are really, really important. Just because an ingredient is lower down the list in one product, doesn't mean that product is worse. It's not as simple as that, unfortunately 😅

And all retinols/derivates are not the same. It does make a difference what kind of derivate you put and how it activates in the skin (they all work differently, the skin has to "convert" them etc). Also, retinols don't thin the skin per se: they thin the upper layer of the skin (where dead skin cells lie) but they actually thicken the deeper layer (increased collagen production). So that's nothing to worry about, it's actually a positive thing.

Oh and because parabens were mentioned: they're fine. Lots of alternatives to them are actually worse. It's just a marketing scam ("it's paraben-free!!" And then people think oh ok that must mean parabens are bad, I should avoid them). I think in the EU they'll ban "paraben-free" claims starting next year because it's misleading consumers on purpose.

Again, loved this video, I don't mean this as negative criticism - just some things to look out for. Skin science is really, really interesting but more complicated than sometimes given credit for. Maybe due to so, so many overblown claims. But I also don't think it's right to equate skincare beauty trends with anti-aging only. There's more to it (moisturizing dry skin, fighting hyperpigmentation, acne, sensitivity issues, etc).

Either way: yes, don't forget the sunscreen. 😉

Polyethylene Glycol (PEG) often contains ethylene oxide and 1,4-Dioxane (carcinogenic)
Sodium Lauryl Sulfate & Sodium Laureth Sulfate (SLS / SLES): carcinogenic
Talc: carcinogenic
Titanium dioxide: carcinogenic
Toluene (especially if pregnant): toxic to the immune system and can cause birth defects
Triclosan: may contribute to inflammation of the gut and trigger tumour growth

Vitamin C is very important in fight against free radicals, pollutants and it also boosts your SPF. Chemically when a free radical is shooting at your face Vitamin C sacrifices it’s electrons instead of letting your skin take it and risk DNA damage. Vitamin C also inhibits melanin production so it’s one of the most naturally (non bleaching) brightening ingredients and in fight of aging, brightening hyperpigmentation and dark spots is also an important part. It’s not effective in the cream because creams are usually pH neutral and science proved effectiveness of Vitamin C at the pH of 3.5~3.6, so putting on a serum on your wet face and then topping it with a cream after you slapped the vitamin C in is the only way it’s proven to be effective.

@ASAPscience The more I watch the video the more annoyed I get because this is such a clear case of the Dunning Kruger effect if there was ever one, yes you might be well versed in science but cosmetic formulation is a completely different field. We also need to remember in science is there is no black or white it's all nuance especially so in skincare. Just because you might be able to read the INCI list it won't tell you much unless you understand product formulation because a product is more than its individual ingredients. Not to poke holes but you forgot the Stratum Lucidium its the layer between the Stratum Granulosum and the Stratum Corneum.

Whilst collagen has absolutely no anti-ageing benefits as can't penetrate the epidermis because its such a massive molecule and even if it was hydrolysed there's no way to know if foreign collagen would actually do anything within the skin but!! it actually makes a pretty good moisturiser because surprisingly enough collagen makes a really good humectant.

I'm sorry but from a scientific perspective on the second round that's not entirely true the moisturiser methylene blue is the weaker product as its a moisturiser whereas Vitamin C in the form of Ascorbic Acid that's in the La Roche Posay Serum is an antioxidant which helps to protect against oxidative damage as well as helping to protect against damage caused by UVA and UVB from the sun. Vit C is often used in the morning before sunscreen for this reason. Vit C is also used because while not the best it has an effect on melanocytes in the skin. It basically inhibits an enzyme called Tyrosinase which causes hyperpigmentation. Dosage is also extremely important, a moisturiser is never going to have the impact that a dedicated serum is going to have. This specific serum has 10% ascorbic acid which won't even compare to Vitamin E.

I'm not going to go into parabens I did a whole post about it on my blog, literally, nothing to be afraid of they arent bad brands just love to fearmonger >> https://www.theskincaresaviour.com/2019/03/parabens.html

Again Retinyl Palmitate is an ester of retinol and palmitic acid and it will not in any way shape or form give you the same effects as "retinol" Retinyl Palmitate will provide some smoothing effects to the skin but it's so weak as it has to undergo conversion 3 times from retinyl palmitate to retinol to retinaldehyde then it becomes retinoic acid and at each conversion, it loses a bit of itself so by the time it makes it all the way to retinoic acid to be used there's so little left that it only superficially smoothes the skin. I have another post here explaining all about retinol >> https://www.theskincaresaviour.com/2019/01/beginners-guide-to-retinol.html

We also need to talk about the claim "Retinol thins the skin" is an old misconception because retinol stimulates fibroblast cells to create more collagen retinol actually thickens the epidermis it doesn't thin it

Another thing you need to be aware of the percentage isn't everything. Skinperspective, a cosmetic chemist on Instagram did a fantastic post about explaining this concept also retinol does not cause you to get sunburn. We apply retinol at night because UV rays degrade retinol so if you used it during the day you'd get no use of it because by the time you'd done anything id would have degraded already but there are retinoids out there that you can use during the day as they have been formulated with photo stabilisers.

If you're interested I have a science-based skincare blog/Instagram where I talk about this kind of stuff on a daily basis. https://www.instagram.com/theskincaresaviour/

I love this video, but I personally think there is slightly misleading information in it. Wish you would’ve gone more in-depth with certain topics. I might be wrong, but anyone feel free to share your opinion/evidence on this.

In my opinion, I don't think your first statement is appropriate. To say that ”this is the only anti-ageing and moisturizing cream that works according to scientists and has a scientific consensus.” is a little misleading. People will assume that this is the only cream/treatment that works and no other topical cream out there regardless of them containing the same main ingredient works. The Skinceuticals retinol creams are definitely some of the best formulas out there, but there are also a handful of other retinol-based products out there that are formulated just as well if not better than this brand-specific one. What you should've said was retinol is one of the only skincare ingredients that work and has the most research and backing.

(6:04) not all antioxidants are the same, but we do know that L-Ascorbic acid is proven to treat and prevent certain concerns in the skin, including collagen biosynthesis. It's a little unfair to say that the Bluelene product is superior to the La Roche Posay one because it contains rice bran oil which contains two antioxidants (tocopherol), vs the one (L-AA) in the La Roche Posay. In actuality the La Roche Posay also contains Tocopherol. L-AA+toco vs two indirect forms of toco.

4:47 it's a little vague to say that ”moisturizers” in it of itself does not have any scientific claims to actually be anti-ageing. Again most research is done on ingredients and not individual branded products. So therefore I also think you're giving people the wrong idea, and that the moisturizer they are currently using isn't doing anything when in reality it probably contains tocopherol, retinol, vitamin c, other antioxidants and derivatives of those. I just thought that was too much a broad statement to make about a category of products.

8:48 dimethicone is shown to have a beneficial effect on the skin. It creates a permeable barrier that works to prevent moisture loss. This is great to have especially for people that have dry and/or dehydrated skin. You can put all the glycerine, and other humectants you want, but if you do not have occlusive ingredients in the formula, there isn't going to be much improvement in your skin when it comes to hydration and moisture levels.

9:30 parabens have been shown to be the best way of preserving, much like phenoxyethanol, a lot of people and brands are demonizing these ingredients when they haven't even read the research to begin with.

10:40 wish you would've gone more in-depth about retinoids as they do not all perform the same. Retinyl palmitate is an ester and the weakest of them all. Esters are often referred to as ”retinol” when in reality they do not contain pure retinol, but a weaker ester.
The skin thinning (epidermis) is only temporary, that's why many people using pure retinol or a retinoic acid prescriptions often suffer from dryness and irritation at the beginning. The epidermis does eventually go back to its normal state, and in reality, over time retinoids help thicken the skin as it is shown to stimulate collagen synthesis.
Retinol is an antioxidant in itself, you can apply them during the day without negative effects.
Retinoids have been studied extensively and have shown that they do not increase sun sensitivity. Retinoids do break down when exposed to sun as they are more unstable and more likely to be less effective that's why a lot of companies are suggesting their products with retinoids for nighttime use only or because their formulas do contain other ingredients that contribute to an increase in sun sensitivity.

- You can't access any retinoic acid/retinoids over the counter (Adapalene/Differin)

I knew this video was going to be misinformed, starting with the description - beauty products are VERY regulated, at least in the US and in the EU, much more so than, say, supplements.

There are marketing claims and there are drug claims, so companies do their best to confuse the consumer. Neither Greg nor Mitch know much about ingredients and their properties, e.g. dimethicone reduces water loss, retinyl palmitate isn't used as a retinoid, I could go on. Also, even the ingredients with research behind them are full of dubious science and misleading results.

I say all this with no malice, I've enjoyed this channel for many years and will continue to do so. I've seen numerous doctors, scientists, and skincare professionals learn and spread misinformation because of how little actual research there is in skincare, so it's only understandable that Greg and Mitch would end up repeating a lot of it.

Dimethicone is not just an additive to make the creams cream. It serves as an occlusive agent to seal in and prevent transepidermal water loss. At the end of your moisturizing routine, you need to make sure that you seal in the water with an occlusive (such as dimethicone, shea butter, or better yet petrolatum), otherwise you will end up losing more water due to evaporation if you just have humectants (like glycerin or hyaluronic acid) holding on to water on top of your skin.

Guys, even though there is no consensus on vitamin C, there is robust evidence that it can help a lot in skin care, especially in collagen synthesis. Vitamin C is essential for collagen synthesis as a co-factor and organization of collagen fibers, it is quite clear that oral ascorbic acid administration increases collagen synthesis and there are some studies showing that topical vit c can increase the localized collagen synthesis. Vitamin C as an acid can help to disrupt the lipid matrix of the stratum corneum and allow transdermal transport, it is often used as an additive to topical drugs as a preservative of the compound as an adjunct to transdermal transport. Thus, Vit C can penetrate, to some degree, the protective structures of the skin and accumulate in the epidermis and reach the dermis, increasing the synthesis of collagen.
All of this is based on studies (I adite, cosmetic research is not the most reliable field of science and they have many bs). Not to say that the cream presented is a good option, just saying that there is some science behind and it is not just the anti-ox effect. You will live 2 studs just as a starting point, there is much more. As for moisturizers, many folks use products that tout it is good for your skin but are actually toxic, especially fragrances [they are laboratory created neurotoxins].but if you really know the "big word" ingredients you'll find that often you're paying a high price for vaseline or petroleum jelly, also not a generally healthy topical.  Yes there are a few therapeutic ingredients that should only be dispensed by an MD as in the retinol items and even the fat soluble vitamins can be harmful when used in excess [ex: vits A, E and D].  ref: EHC-Dallas et al
